Hello!
Can anyone suggest me, what should i read, to get known, how to work in this situation?
I have an application, that should have open socket connection whole life-time. This connection instance lives in singletone object, which is reinited each time Application#onCreate() called. 
So i want to learn about situations, when application may die and on re-creation my connection would not be established. 
Also i want to know, if android CAN kill this connection.

Application is being created first, before any app components created.
Android can kill your process like the other ones. You can use foreground service to try avoiding your process death. Also you can try making this connection in a very lightweight process so it will less likely to be killed, but note that all of your app’s processes go through Application#onCreate.

<@U2M0WUZ7A> so… if application’s process killed, i can be sure, that if user will try to open app from recents, Application#onCreate will be called?

and also about service: can service start itself in Service#onDestroy()?

p.s. are u from Russia?

Yes, you can check yourself, onCreate is called first in a fresh process.
You can try starting a service in onDestroy, but this method may be ignored by Android if it have to free some memory.
Такие дела :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U2M0WUZ7A> so… one of the best solutions is foreground service?

кек :thinking_face:
Background service (to be less likely killed) or sticky service (to be resurrected).
хотя, не думаю, что тут банят за русский :thinking_face:
<@U2M0WUZ7A> спасибо
не банят, могут сказать guys, english please :slightly_smiling_face:
не, ну эт пусть говорят

Actually I think I've got it
<@U3WPNLJ4Q|pavinthan> has joined the channel
Would this return a list of size 2 if both conditions are right?
<@U2QHEEGBX|nesho> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/nesho/F3XD93883/-.java|Untitled>

file.name: -.java
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
RealmResults<Adult> getParents(List<Adult> parents){
        Realm realm = Realm.getDefaultInstance();
        return realm.where(Adult.class).beginGroup().equalTo("socialSecurityNumber", parents.get(0).getSocialSecurityNumber()).or().equalTo("socialSecurityNumber", parents.get(1).getSocialSecurityNumber()).endGroup().findAll();
    }

text: does anyone go through the trouble of abstracting image loading to an interface instead of using picasso/glide directly? i had done that while we were using picasso, and now we're trying to switch to glide, it's gotten to be a huge pain to maintain both implementations. i'm pushing for us to just rip out the interface and use glide directly but some of my team is hesitant
Blergh on interfaces :smile:
for example, for transformations i had to make the interface accept a transformation factory class that returns an instance of the correct class. but it was a little weird
K.I.S.S
And I'm off to party, cya lads. Happy coding :smile:

yeah that's how i feel. my teammate was asking if we can add support for a `Bitmap get()` method and i looked into it and both libraries handle it slightly differently, it wouldn't really be that simple
i learned that lesson of abstracting out libs with networking/persistence
_the hard way_
i guess it depends on the app - if there’s a lot of image manipulation, you’re best to try and abstract the use-cases
that's the thing, using so many different parts of the API is what makes it hard to maintain
if we were just doing `glide.with().load().into()` everywhere it would be easy, but some places need circle transformations, some places need callbacks, some places need `asBitmap`
if we end up wanting to use a another transformation class, we'll need another transformation factory. or a transformation factory factory
they're mostly worried about the case if we end up wanting to switch libraries again. i honestly doubt we will; picasso was fine, but we want gif support now, that's the only reason we're switching
i guess its figuring out the line to draw and not become an onion of abstraction
Maybe you'll switch to fresco for images in the future. :trollface:
that was the supposed library my teammate suggested would be a possible change. i promptly asserted that would not be happening lol

It is a balance to figure out how much to abstract. We currently use Picasso but will likely be switching to Glide in the future for gif support. Luckily we just use the basics of Picasso and don't apply transformations or anything of that sort so switching to Glide will be straight forward.
When we do the switch, we will likely have a discussion about creating an interface should we decide to switch to something different in the future.
yeah i think either way it's a pain in the ass
<@U0546QERR> :taco: :nutella: for shutting down fresco talk :stuck_out_tongue:
if you abstract to an interface, it's a pain to maintain for using new APIs. if you use the libraries directly, it's a pain if you switch libs
i'd say transformations were the worst pain point though. if you don't have those, you can keep the interface somewhat sane

Ok, thanks. Related question — what do people usually use for creating release APKs, the `./gradlew assembleRelease command` or the Android Studio “Generate Signed APK” menu option?
Android Studio's method is a wrapper around Gradle so it's basically the same

If you don't know what you're doing with Gradle, use Android Studio.
So I’m deducting that you have a problem with the photo/gallery intent? Do you know which Android version the Z3 is running?

The only problem I have with Generate Signed APK vs the gradle command is that it requires me to manually enter the key store path and passwords, while the gradle command uses the info in the gradle file to get it from my keystore.properties file (which I setup based on "Remove signing information from your build files” in <https://developer.android.com/studio/publish/app-signing.html>)
It'll remember it after you sign at least 1 build.
